segments.text: Now, first I'd like you to explain to me your educational background.
How and why did you acquire your degree?
Where did you go to school?
What were your interests?
Well, I was born over in eastern Washington in 1905.
on a farm between two trout streams.
I went to the proverbial one-room schoolhouse for a number of years until I got to about the eighth grade when I went to high school.
The eighth grade I took in town to prepare for the high school, which I attended and graduated in 19.
Well, this is just after, shortly after World War I.
At times, we weren't quite in the Depression then, but times weren't too good.
decided when I got through high school, which was 1922, that I was going to go on to university.
I thought that I could better myself by going to university.
But first I had to go out and make a little bit of money before I could do that.
So I worked in the lumber mills and
harvest fields and on concrete gangs and section gangs and what not.
In a couple of years I had enough of a stake to come on to university.
Well in high school I sort of liked physics and sciences.
One thing we didn't have was chemistry.
So I looked over the field then and it looked to me as though if you took

chemistry and did fairly well in it why you had a broad spectrum that you could later go into and so I took chemistry and but I wasn't able to go full-time too long I'd work on the side and lay off and from school
and work, so I didn't finish up my bachelor's until about 1930.
During this time, I continued my work in different manual endeavors.
piling lumber and a few things like that.
As a matter of fact, I made more money piling lumber than I did for many years after I had my Ph.D.
But one of the chemistry professors here was Professor Honesty Thompson.
And so I was in his
quant class in chemistry and qualitative analysis class.
Later on, I was his teaching fellow.
And he got me interested in some of the work that was going on.
One of the first things we did that he was concerned with was a saltwater intrusion into Lake Washington and Lake Union system through the ship canal.
And so we went there with a bunch of us as students, graduate students.
We worked on this problem to see the efficiency of the locks and getting rid of the salt water that they brought back into the lake and into the canal system.
This started me, got me interested in water movements, water chemistry, water flow.
So, I ended up by getting a, finally got a master's, or finally got a doctorate in the fall of 36.
here at the university in chemistry with a minor in physics.
But before that time, I was at Friday Harbor with Dr. Thompson in 1931 and 1932 when this building was
was built.
He had gotten some Rockefeller funds to build this building here on the campus with.
And he had organized the oceanographic laboratories.
And so we worked out of Friday Harbor in the summer outside the school year from June through August.
working on the waters of the system from the Strait of Juan de Fuca into the Strait of Georgia and into Puget Sound.
Then in 1933, the opportunity came to go with the Navy up to Adak and make some oceanographic observations.
making a survey of the harbors, the waters around Adak.
And so this gave me an opportunity to go out in the field.
And then I left my teaching fellowship here.
I got someone else to pinch hit for me.
And I went up in May and didn't get back until, oh, long in September.
And I did some of the first oceanographic work.
by U.S. up in the Bering Sea.
And next summer, I went up on a Coast Guard vessel and worked from the Aleutian Islands up through Bering Strait and the eastern part of Bering Sea.
And this material,
was the basis of my doctoral dissertation.
By the time I got through, there were really no jobs in oceanography in that day.
No one knew of oceanographers.
In fact, one well-known man,
from Texas and Fisheries that I knew said that he didn't have any use for oceanography and he wouldn't know an oceanographer if he saw one.
And what's more, he never expected a need or hire one.
Well, this was along in the Depression days.
And as a part-time work, before I got my degree, I also joined some other labs and set up a spray residue laboratory.
Then people were becoming concerned with the arsenic and the lead on apples.
So I worked with the pure food and drugs.
and then I had our own private lab.
It didn't make too much money because it was seasonal, but that gave me a little boost.
And then when I finally finished up in 1936, the depression was still pretty strong, but one of my
co-teaching fellows, Bert Thomas, who was later president and director of Battelle Memorial Institute, had gone back to Columbus and was just getting pretty well established.
And when I came along, he urged me to come back to Columbus, Ohio at Battelle, which I did from late 1936.
through until 1940.
But I was still looking for some way to get back out to sea.
As you know, Columbus is pretty well landlocked.
And a civil service announcement came through for someone, a physical oceanographer,
work with the International Ice Patrol.
And so I applied, filled in my application for that, sent in my resume, and I was chosen to fill that billet.
And at the time, I think, I ended up, at that time, I think I was one of three physical oceanographers and employee of the United States government.
The other one, Floyd Sowell, also being up, another one being on the International Ice Board all night, and the other one, I guess, was down in Washington.
So I went to Woods Hole in 1940, and a typical New England blizzard drove up from Columbus, Ohio, and it was the last car on the road before
I finally got into a Falmouth Mass and took a night's lodging before I pushed on to Woods Hole because the drifts were three and four feet deep across the road.
And then I joined Floyd's Soul on the International Ice Patrol.
This was in February of 1940.
In March, we pushed off for the Grand Banks

with the summer base at Newfoundland, St. John's, to work out the dynamics of the flow patterns in the ice patrol area so that we could predict about where the birds would move and to afford guidance to the maritime interests
so they could avoid the iceberg areas as a basis of changing the routes depending on how much ice we had and how many birds we had down in the area and so on.
Well, I was on that job in 1940, but things were beginning to get a little sticky along in 1940.
So we...
I cruised the east and west coasts of Greenland, up as far as Cape York on the west coast, throughout Baffin Bay, and doing a little bit of seeing how things were going.
You weren't hunting for German submarines?
Not submarines.
We did pick up a few people.
One of them was a good Norwegian, Willie Knudsen, who had
We picked up in East Greenland and brought him out to the States.
The Knudsen family is famous in oceanography.
And I saw him some years later when he was a captain in the Air Force.
But then in 1941, it was more or less a repeat
One of the things that we did do was do, in 1940, we heard a number of SOS's when we were out on ice patrol.
So we put in St. John's and

I cruised up towards Denmark's strait where the ships had been torpedoed, and with Sol and the skipper and the staff, we worked out the probable position of where the drifting boats might be, and we got up into the area.
On one day, I think it was Sunday, we heard the
planes overhead, which is very unusual for that part of the North Atlantic.
We couldn't dope it out, and our codes wouldn't break any of the messages, so we didn't have high enough classification for that.
During the night, we heard that the hood had been sunk.
Did you find any survivors?
We picked up two lifeboats, not from this supply, but from the torpedoed ships, TS Marconi.
We picked up their SOS and got their approximate position.
We picked up two of those lifeboats.
It was in dense fog.
And we'd run a little ways and stop.
And one time when we were stopped, we heard voices out on the sea.
And one of the boats, we kept blasting our new whistle.
And one of the boats came right up alongside us.
We took them aboard.
They went out about six, seven days then, because we had to come in from patrol.
And we fueled and provisioned to go up and pick them up.
And then during that.
a break while we were continuing our search.
We heard some very heavy cannonading going on.
But being on a 125-footer painted white, we didn't have any particular qualms about that.
And so on the breaks, we found another lifeboat.
We picked it up.
So we picked up 39 survivors.
We had 36 aboard our own ship, and we brought them back to St. John's.
Well, at the end of 1941, of course, by that time, we were getting involved.
So instead of working out of Woods Hole and getting back once in a while,
was assigned to Argentia and slapped into a uniform.
Spent from then until about 1946, early 1946, on the scouting for eyes.
First I hitchhiked on the different planes, then I got some planes
and finally a few ships to run around up there.
Played around in the North Atlantic and covered the area from the Nova Scotian and Grand Banks up through Baffin Bay, Ungava Bay, and west to Churchill.
So that was my area.
Were you trying to trace the sea lanes open for the Navy?
What we were doing was two things.

First, we were trying to be able to predict ahead of time where the ice edge would be found so that we could try to keep them close to it but not into it so that we could cover the ships by plane from a land base to keep the subs down.
then be able to have enough flexibility to make the convoy routings so that we wouldn't cross paths with convoys and all these things that you have to be aware of besides the ice in the area.
And then the problem also was being able to predict as soon as we could get the ships into where we were...
putting the bases in for running small planes, because at that time it appeared as though we might have to fly a lot of small planes across to Europe.
And so we had bases, airstrips, through a part of the area over in Greenland and up in the Canadian, northern Canada.

Part of the problem was to be able to predict just when the ice would open up so you could get the ships into the base without them setting off the ice edge and setting docks for any protracted period where they were vulnerable.
And so this was the...
the sequence there.
And then...
Were you trying to base your predictions on ocean currents?
We used, yes.
Insofar as around Grand Banks, we always made our dynamic charts.
And in the days pre-calculator or pre the modern electronic devices,
Sol and myself would get out a chart of the dynamic topography, which would give us some idea of the probable ice drift.
And we generally completed the chart within two hours after we took our last oceanographic station.
And so we had a good picture of where the icebergs would tend to come down on the eastern edge of the Grand Banks.
where they would switch over into the extension of the Gulf Stream, the North Atlantic Current, and start off to the Northeast.
And it was this important part that enabled us to set the shipping lanes and convoy routes, because you
The shortest way, by great circle, would cut right across the banks, right through the ice area.
And so we liked to be able to route them as close as possible without getting into ice difficulty.
So along came 1936, and we were
through with this particular job and I got orders to go to Washington and the Marshall Islands.
Ah, okay.
And so I went from Argentia, Newfoundland through Frisco to Hawaii at the Marshall Islands without coming back through Seattle.
the family being in Seattle when I was away for about five years.
And so we were out on the bow ditch to make the pre-survey of Bikini, to find out something about the currents, to establish the...
the biological regimes, to get a survey of those, both on shore on the different islands of the atolls, both at Bikini and at Inuitak and at Ronzeland.
Who worked with you in measuring the currents here?
Well, I had some of the then, I would say, the young bloods in the game with me on the Bowditch.
Roger Revell was on another ship that had sort of an overall project, but I was on the physical subgroup that was on the Bowditch that did the preliminary survey.
So we had Walter Monk, Gordon Riley, Martin Johnson, Marston Sargent, and Bill Van Arks, Bill Ford, one of the Canadian chaps with us, Tommy Austin,
Hal Turner from Woods Hole.
Most of the people were from Woods Hole.
One, except for Walter Monk and some of the others, we had
William Randolph Taylor from Michigan, Leonard P. Schultz from the National Museum.
We picked up several people who are still in the service one way or the other, one service or another.
Mel Traylor had been with the Marines.
He was one of my assistants.
We had Vern Brock from Hawaii, and a number of others.
Ken Emery from USC and Scripps.
So we had a fairly sizable group.
that we used in this survey starting in about February when we got out there and all set up in 1946.
We carried through Project Abel and Baker and I got back to Washington D.C. along about September of that year.
Had you known any of those guys before?
Some I had known.
Of course, Martin Johnson was originally from the University of Washington.
I knew him.
Schultz had been here for a while.
Donaldson over in fisheries was on one of the other ships.
So I knew some of that group.
It was my first meeting with some of the younger people.
That was the first time you met Walter Mook, wasn't it?
I met...
I think so, although I've been down at...
I believe this was the first time that I actually met Walter.
What did you expect to happen when you discovered they were going to drop a bomb?
Did you have any anticipation of events?
I think, as you know, there's lots of things we didn't know, just what the bomb would do and all.
But we did, I think, come up with a pretty fair analysis of what was likely to happen with the radiation that got into the water.
We had, in fact, built on arcs, went back to Woods Hole and built a little model to help out some of our studies.
He was able to make enough checks with our field measurements.
We had a pretty good feeling of what was going to happen to the stuff that got into the water.
a job to really look at that that went into the atmosphere, because we didn't know that.
But if it did come down in the water in the area, we knew enough about the general currents and so on to know a little bit about where to expect it to go.
So I believe that we had a good feeling for the limits
of what might be put on it.
And nothing came amiss as far as what wasn't within the realm of what we knew.
And afterwards, of course, we had to go in and do a little bit of some measurements to get an idea of how it had
obeyed what we thought might happen.
And also to take a reassessment of some of the biota in the system.
And you were reasonably satisfied with the results?
You think you did a pretty good job when you went back in?
I think we did a reasonable job.
Now, with our
with our group there.
And I have a picture of that group that was with me that I'll show you later that you may be interested in.
But it seemed to be pretty well in hand by the time along about the first of September, late August, when I finally felt that I could leave.
and get back to Washington, D.C.
So I returned to Washington, D.C. and wound up some of my immediate duties there and made arrangements to move my family possessions from
Woods Hole to Washington, DC.
And I came back and took a little time off before I went back to Washington to join Dick Fleming in the Hydrographic Office.
oceanography section there, which was just being set up at that time.
So I was in hydro with Dick Fleming, and we had two people that had been out with us, two or three people that had actually been out with us on the Bikini.
I came back, John Lyman was one of them, and Tommy Austin.
another and Horace Whaley was another and later went to Chesapeake Bay Institute.
